text: Massachusetts Driver's License and duly sworn by the Notary Public, was examined and testified as follows: EXAMINATION CONDUCTED
Good morning.  My name is Mallarie Charbonneau, as I've already said.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Just to get it on the record, usual stipulations?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. KATSARAS

text: So all objections, except to form, will be waived until trial, including motions to strike.  The witness will have 30 days upon reading the transcript to sign the transcript.  And notary waived.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: So could you please state your name and date of birth for the record?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Robert Peabody, 8/21/71.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And have you ever been deposed before?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: What?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever been deposed before?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I'm just going to go over a couple of quick rules so you understand a little bit more how this process works.  So the first and foremost, it's important to answer audibly.  She is taking down everything we say for the record, so things like uh-huhs and uh-uh, shoulder shrugs aren't going to come across clear.  So if you do use those answers, I might gently remind you just to get a verbal record of what your response is.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And because she's typing, it's really hard for her to do that when we're speaking over each other.  If you could just wait until I'm finished asking the questioning, so that way she gets everything down correctly. If you don't understand a question, please let me know.  I'm happy to clarify and make sure that you're clear.  Please don't guess when you're answering.  If you don't know or you can't remember, just let us know.  And at the end of this or at some point at the end of this deposition you will be given a transcript, and you'll be able to review that and make any notes, if you think something is misstated, in an errata sheet at the end.  And then you'll be asked to sign and get that back to us within 30 days of receipt.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Could you please state your current address?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: My home or my work?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Your work, please?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: 90 Hampshire Street, Methuen, Mass.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you married?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any kids?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I have one that's my son, and I have two stepsons and a stepdaughter.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just to get a brief educational background, did you finish high school?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you have any postsecondary education?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I just had some college.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  About a semester, more than a semester?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: More.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you get an associate's degree?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just some classes.  Did you spend any time in the military?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We appreciate your service.  Are you part of any labor unions, any trade groups?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Just the police union.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And where are you currently employed?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: City of Methuen.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And for how long?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Eight years, almost nine years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is your position there?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Police officer.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is just a brief description of your duties there?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: To protect and serve the community and patrol the areas.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any prior positions with the state of -- with Methuen?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you aware of this lawsuit before receiving --
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- this notice?  Were you aware of the underlining facts from which it comes?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Well, I am aware of it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you know the plaintiff in this action, Daniel Kelley, at all?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Just when I went to the call.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you do anything to prepare for this deposition?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you speak with Daniel Kelley any time before the accident and after the accident?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Just during, just when I went to the call.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you remember responding to an incident at DeLucca Fence Company on September 19, 2017?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When were you made aware of that incident?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: What do you mean as far as when?  I don't remember exact time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember the time of day?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: It was during the daytime.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would you say before noon?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I'm not sure.  I mean, I had my report, but, like I said, I was involved in an accident.  My report was in my truck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I can get it faxed if you need me to do that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I actually have a copy here. We'll go over it.  Actually, I'll do that now. Do you recognize the title of this report, Methuen Police Department?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then I'm going to direct you to the second to last page.  Is that your name listed as the reporting officer?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes, it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'll mark that as Exhibit 1.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: (Exhibit No. 1, Police Report so marked)
If you look at that second to last page, again, the second paragraph says you were alerted at about 10:24 hours in the morning. Do you remember that to be correct?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So do you recall about what time you arrived on the scene?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Within minutes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Within minutes I was right down the street.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anyone else arrive with you?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Later my supervisor arrived on scene and Methuen Fire.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What's his name?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Sergeant DeLano, Sergeant John DeLano.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And about how long after you arrived did he arrive?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Probably 15, 20 minutes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anyone else arrive on the scene?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Methuen Fire.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did you observe when you got to the scene?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I observed -- I forgot his name --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Mr. Kelley?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: -- Mr. Kelley laying inside of a dumpster.  I told him not to move, you know, because of possible injury, and I didn't want to harm him any more.  When we do that, it's typically we let the fire department so that way we don't harm them, you know, cause him any more physical harm.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you speak to him at all other than that?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did you say?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I asked him what happened, and I remember him saying that he was dropping off an empty dumpster and picking up a full dumpster. He said once he dropped off the empty dumpster, he stood on top of the dumpster, the side, and was pushing material down so he could pull the dumpster away.  And he said that he slipped and fell into the empty dumpster.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I'll have you take a look at this.  Do you recall this scene when you arrived?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And are these the two dumpsters you were talking about?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We're going to mark this as Exhibit 2.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: (Exhibit No. 2, Photocopy of Photograph so marked)
Was the ambulance there when you arrived?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No, I was there first.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  The ambulance arrived sometime after?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: About how long after, would you say?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Five minutes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so the dumpster to the right with the Crescio label, is that where Mr. Kelley was found?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: By your recollection, he would have dropped off that empty dumpster?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: First.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then repositioned the blue truck to pick up the full dumpster to the left?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Take a look at this.  Do you remember seeing this when you reported to the scene?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.  I actually took these pictures, just so you know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And those are the same two dumpsters we were talking about before?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you see your blue truck in that photo?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: As far as I can tell, that's my truck on the right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Perfect.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Mark that as Exhibit 3.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: (Exhibit No. 3, Photocopy of Photograph so marked)
Is that your police vehicle on the right there?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No, that truck belongs to my supervisor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know who the person in the hard hat is next to that vehicle?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No.  I don't recall who it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you know who the person to the left of the truck is?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I don't recall that either.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Is there anything that stands out to you about this photo?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I mean, I've seen dumpsters drop off. I mean, nothing that really stands out.  I've seen the same scene before in the past.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Nothing that strikes your attention?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Well, I mean, not really, honestly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you were there, did you speak to anyone besides Mr. Kelley?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.  I spoke with several people.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Who did you speak with?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I spoke with this Chris Stephens and Daniel Shanahan.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you remember what you spoke to Chris Stephens about?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I asked him what happened because they were the ones that called.  One of them called. And they said they stopped -- they were operating forklifts, and when they stopped to talk to each other, they shut off the fork lifts.  They could hear someone yelling inside the dumpster for help.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember which of those two individuals said that to you?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Well, they both said they heard it, they heard someone yelling for help.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is this the dumpster that you recall seeing Mr. Kelley in?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We're going to mark this as Exhibit 4.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: (Exhibit No. 4, Photocopy of Photograph so marked)
When you saw Mr. Kelley in there, how was he positioned?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I have to refer -- he was laying on his left side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you remember which way he was facing in that image?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I think kind of at an angle.  I mean, I don't remember exactly, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember if his feet were closer to the door or closer towards the back wall?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: To the side wall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To the side wall.  And do you mean the right side wall?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: If I'm looking at it, the side with the door on it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  His head would have been closer towards the back wall?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: He would have been positioned on his left side?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you see him try to move at all?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that how he landed?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Well, he said -- well, he did say he tried to catch himself when he fell, but he landed on his left hip first on the bottom of the dumpster.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you notice anything else when you saw him in the dumpster?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: He had on no kind of safety gear at all, you know.  I mean, that's the only thing I noticed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you notice what kind of shoes he was wearing?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I think -- I don't remember, but I think it was work boots, leather work boots.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'll have you take a look at this. Are these the two dumpsters that you recall seeing on the date of the incident?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the dumpster to the left is the one you saw Mr. Kelley in?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We'll mark that as Exhibit 5.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: (Exhibit No. 5, Photocopy of Photograph so marked)
Is the dumpster on the left the one Mr. Kelley was found in?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so that would be the dumpster he told you he dropped off, correct?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then the dumpster to the right, that would be the full one he was there to pick up, correct?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yeah, correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So to your knowledge, where was he standing when he fell?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Objection.
speaker: MR. KATSARAS

text: Yeah.  I didn't see him fall, and I didn't see any video.  So, I mean, I only went on what I was told by witnesses when I was on scene.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When he told you he was standing on the top, do you know if he meant the top rail there?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes, along the top.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you notice how wide that rail was?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I want to say approximately 4 to 5 inches.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember how much space is in between those dumpsters?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I don't remember exactly but approximately, you know, 2 to 3 feet.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would it have been wide enough for someone to walk in between?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: It would have been tight for someone big like me.  I probably wouldn't have fit between there with all my gear on but...
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to have you go back to the incident report and flip over to the photo with the images.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: (Witness complies)
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's on the third page.  And just so it's right side up.  Are these the photos that you took?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And earlier you said the photos I just showed you were also photos you took?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So are these five photos in the report similar, or are they the same photos I just showed you, or are they different?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: They're different than the ones I added.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Is there anything that stands out to you in the photos in the incident report?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I don't see -- well, I don't see the ambulance in this one.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Looking at the top left photo in the incident report holding it horizontally, is that the dumpster where Mr. Kelley was found?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And one photo to the right, so the top middle photo, does that show the dumpster he was found?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I'm making sure this is the one you're talking about.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.  The top middle?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And to the right, is that the dumpster, adjacent picture there?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember when you saw the truck if there was any kind of fixtures attached with a tarp?  It's not -- sorry.  You can answer.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I didn't -- I don't recall it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It would have been -- it's not pictured in these, but it would have been attached to the back and able -- you would have been able to roll it out.  Do you recall seeing anything like that?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No.  No, but I'm familiar with the process, so I'm sure it had -- I mean, once a dumpster is up, they usually cover it to secure the load from flying on the highway, debris from falling out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you got to the scene, do you remember speaking with Jackie DeLucca at all?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did you speak to her about?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Well, I asked ask her, you know, if she seen -- or I asked about the video that was on because they do have cameras.  I'm aware of that.  I've been there for many other calls for crime, people stealing product off there.  So I asked her about the cameras.  And she said in the camera footage, she can see him walking along the top of the dumpster, but as it oscillated, she didn't see the actual fall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you view this footage?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know if anyone else did?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Not that I know of.  She did.  She said she viewed it and saw it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember if any of the other reporting officers saw it?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Not that I know of.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you remember any other witnesses to the incident?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: There was another male party, Jimmy. I can't even say his name but.  I can't even say it.  Down at the bottom.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Georgoulakos, does that sound right?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did he say?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: He said he saw someone.  He actually -- he was parked outside the property, so there's Ferry Road.  It borders the property of DeLucca Fence, and he said he was parked outside there.  And he observed out of the corner of his eye what appears someone had fallen into the dumpster.  He only saw the hips and the legs go up and over, but he didn't actually see his head go in, but he saw...
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you speak with anyone else at the incident scene?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Just my supervisor.  Other than that...
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did you two talk about?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: I asked him what -- is this something I should get OSHA involved in, you know, because it is like an industrial place, so occasionally we would contact OSHA.  And he said -- he advised me to contact OSHA, and I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did he advise you to do anything else?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Take pictures.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you take any video at all?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Well, my body camera.  I believe my body camera was working at the time as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that something you still have access to?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: The department might have it.  You have to -- it has to be a request to the department to obtain that photo or that, if it's still there.  I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then the photos in the incident report, were those also taken with your body camera?
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: They were taken with an iPod.  We were issued department-issued iPods, and I took them with the iPod and uploaded it to evidence.com.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's all the questions I have.  Thank you so much. EXAMINATION CONDUCTED
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Good morning.  My name is Alex Katsaras.  I represent the plaintiff in the matter.  I have, I think, just one or two quick questions.  In Exhibit 1 the narrative, there's some pictures.  There's five pictures.  The one on the top middle that was referenced previously has two dumpsters in it?
speaker: MR. KATSARAS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That dumpster with the wood, do you remember at that time if that wood was above the seams of the dumpster?
speaker: MR. KATSARAS

text: Slightly.  I kind of remember slightly, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did it look more full than any other dumpster there, if you remember?
speaker: MR. KATSARAS

text: I mean, the empty one beside it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Besides the empty one?
speaker: MR. KATSARAS

text: I didn't really pay attention to any other dumpster besides those two.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  You said you were familiar with the process.  Do you know if that looked too full for you compared to other dumpsters you've seen?
speaker: MR. KATSARAS

text: Objection.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Do I answer?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You still answer.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: Being familiar with the process, I know that this is typically done where they go up and they help level a load off before they pick up the dumpster, and then they tarp it, like I said, for safety, public safety.  I mean, for the roadway too because you don't want the debris falling out or blowing out. I've seen this happen, you know.  This isn't the first time, I mean, I've seen somebody walk on the dumpster.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yeah.  Was this the first time you had a call to this place for this type of injury?
speaker: MR. KATSARAS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. KATSARAS

text: I think that's all I have.
speaker: MR. KATSARAS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. CHARBONNEAU

text: (Whereupon, the deposition concluded at 10:20 a.m.) C E R T I F I C A T E COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS COUNTY OF MIDDLESEX, ss. I, Darlene Caiazzo Sousa, a Certified Shorthand Reporter, Licensed Court Reporter NH #139, Registered Professional Reporter and Notary Public in and for the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, do hereby certify that the foregoing transcript of the deposition of ROBERT PEABODY, having been duly sworn, on Friday, March 13, 2020, is true and accurate to the best of my knowledge, skill and ability. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand and seal this 23rd day of March, 2020.

_________________________________ Darlene Caiazzo Sousa, Notary Public My commission expires:  November 5, 2021 DEPONENT'S ERRATA SHEET AND SIGNATURE INSTRUCTIONS The original of the Errata Sheet has been delivered to Mallarie Charbonneau, Esq. DO NOT make marks or notations on the transcript volume itself. REPLACE THIS PAGE OF THE TRANSCRIPT WITH THE COMPLETED AND SIGNED ERRATA SHEET WHEN RECEIVED.
